prior_works.title: Space-Time Embedded Intelligence
prior_works.role: Foundational formalization of agents embedded within their environments
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This paper directly builds on Orseau and Ring’s embedded-agent viewpoint by instantiating an agent as an automaton simulated inside a universal computer and proving that embeddedness itself induces implicit constraints.

prior_works.title: Universal Artificial Intelligence: Sequential Decisions based on Algorithmic Probability
prior_works.role: Universal-computation framing of agent–environment interaction via a universal Turing machine
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The new work leverages Hutter’s universal computation perspective but departs from the Cartesian separation by embedding the agent within the universal computer, using this setting to derive capacity-independent implicit constraints.

prior_works.title: Provably Bounded-Optimal Agents
prior_works.role: Classical theory of agents that are optimal given explicit computational limits
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Contrasting with Russell and Subramanian’s explicit resource bounds, the paper shows that embeddedness yields implicit constraints that hold regardless of nominal capacity, thereby avoiding ad hoc bounding choices.

prior_works.title: Information-Theoretic Bounded Rationality
prior_works.role: Information-theoretic formulation of decision making under explicit information constraints (e.g., KL or channel limits)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The presented approach replaces explicit information constraints typified by Tishby–Polani with implicit constraints arising from computation being embedded in the environment’s simulation.

prior_works.title: Learning Finite-State Controllers for Partially Observable Environments
prior_works.authors: Nicolas Meuleau, Kee-Eung Kim, Leslie Pack Kaelbling, Anthony R. Cassandra
prior_works.role: Establishes finite-state controllers as automaton representations of POMDP policies
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By modeling the embedded agent as an automaton, the paper relies on the finite-state controller view to formalize and then prove equivalence to an agent interacting with a POMDP.

prior_works.title: Bounded Finite State Controllers for Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
prior_works.role: Optimization of resource-bounded POMDP policies represented as finite-state controllers
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The work connects to Poupart–Boutilier by framing the agent as a controller/automaton, but shows that the relevant constraints emerge implicitly from computational embedding rather than being imposed as fixed bounds.

prior_works.title: Embedded Agency
prior_works.role: Conceptual articulation of problems that arise when agents are embedded in their environments
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This paper operationalizes the Embedded Agency agenda by giving a concrete computational model of embeddedness and proving that such agents are implicitly constrained and equivalent to POMDP-interacting automata.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution—formalizing a computationally embedded agent as an automaton simulated within a universal computer, and proving that embeddedness induces implicit constraints and an equivalence to a POMDP-interacting agent—sits at the intersection of embedded agency, universal computation, and bounded rationality. Orseau and Ring’s Space-Time Embedded Intelligence is the most direct antecedent, replacing the traditional Cartesian boundary with an agent that is part of the environment; the present work instantiates this idea concretely and derives formal constraints from it. Hutter’s universal AI framework supplies the universal computation substrate and the agent–environment interface; the authors adapt this setting by embedding the agent in the universal simulator rather than treating it as external. Classic bounded rationality lines—Russell and Subramanian’s bounded-optimal agents and Tishby–Polani’s information-theoretic bounded rationality—motivate the role of limits but rely on explicit resource or information constraints; the new perspective shows such limits arise implicitly from being simulated within the environment, sidestepping ad hoc constraint design. The automaton-based representation draws on the POMDP literature: Meuleau et al.’s finite-state controllers establish automata as policy representations for partially observable environments, and Poupart–Boutilier provide optimization tools for bounded controllers. Finally, Demski and Garrabrant’s Embedded Agency frames the conceptual challenges of embeddedness; this paper advances that agenda by proving equivalence results and constraint properties that ground continual adaptation in a principled, computationally embedded setting.
